sections.title: Common Volume Units
content: Metric: Milliliter (mL), Liter (L), Cubic Meter (mÂ³) - universal standard for science and most countries
US Customary: Fluid Ounce, Cup, Pint, Quart, Gallon - standard in American recipes and retail
Imperial: Imperial Gallon (20% larger than US gallon!) - used in UK and former British colonies
Industrial: Barrel (bbl) - oil industry standard (42 US gallons or 158.987 liters)
Cooking: Cups and fluid ounces vary between US and metric - always verify your recipe's system!

sections.title: Common Questions
content: Q: What's the difference between US and Imperial gallons? A US gallon is 3.785 liters (128 fl oz), while an Imperial (UK) gallon is 4.546 liters (160 fl oz) - about 20% larger. This is crucial for fuel efficiency comparisons. When someone says their car gets '30 mpg', always ask if they mean US or Imperial gallons!

Q: Why do US and metric cups differ? A US cup is 236.588 mL (8 fl oz), while a metric cup used in Australia and New Zealand is exactly 250 mL. This 14 mL difference (about 6%) can significantly affect baking results, especially in delicate recipes like soufflÃ©s or macarons.

Q: How accurate do volume measurements need to be for baking? For most cooking, Â±5% is acceptable. For baking (bread, cakes, pastries), aim for Â±2% accuracy as ratios are critical for chemical reactions. For professional baking or laboratory work, use Â±0.1% precision. Pro tip: weigh liquids on a kitchen scale for maximum accuracy.

Q: Can I use this for fuel efficiency conversions? Yes! To convert mpg (miles per gallon) to L/100km: divide 235.214 by your mpg. For example, 30 mpg = 235.214/30 = 7.84 L/100km. Note: this uses US gallons. For Imperial gallons (UK), divide 282.481 by mpg instead.

Q: Why are barrels used in the oil industry? The 42-US-gallon barrel became the oil industry standard in 1866 for historical reasons (it was a common shipping container size). Even though oil is pumped via pipelines and stored in tanks, pricing and contracts still use barrels. 1 barrel = 158.987 liters.
